text: I already said what I thought of that new permission system in my article, but to sum up here: I think we can do better than this.
It’s not good for users, not good for us -devs- either.

initial_comment.comment: How to get this Heart in center of two layouts.

text: Framelayout would do the job

FrameLayout
         ImageView (the top image)
         *Layout (whatever you need to do the bottom layout, prob a RelativeLayout)
         ImageButton (the heart)

Thanks <@U0542GLTE>
He meant you can put the heart itself in the frame layout, and leave everything else in the original layout
So you would have the relativelayout with all the other stuff in it, and then a frame layout with the heart image in it that is centered and then margin adjusted if you want

Your other option is to keep it in the relative layout, put it at the bottom (since it will render last) and then align it center and top with the white part, and then give margin bottom at half the height
That saves you a layout
Thanks.

does anyone here use Parse for notifications?
I wondering how I can use an image from the web as the largeIcon, but the problem is I can’t pull it in the `getLargeIcon` method because it has to be done asynchronously
I guess you could implement a receiver for those notifications, get the icon url, load it, and once you have it, show the notification
use parse, but never tried that sry

parse handles showing the actual notification though
they allow you to override getLargeIcon, which returns a bitmap
I don’t think you can set it after the fact
the use case is that the notifications come from users, so we need to load their avatar to show in the notification

yeah, parse can show the notification for you. but if you have to load an image from internet, you might have no choice but "intercept" that notification and build your own when you have the avatar ready

agh
but then we can’t make use of the parse analytics :disappointed:
I wonder if we can just encode the image into a string and send it with the actual notification, and decode it on the phone
I think you can, why not? you only have to subclass their receiver
<https://parse.com/docs/android/guide#push-notifications-managing-the-push-lifecycle>

yeah, that’s probably the easiest way to do it without having to mess around with how the notification creation works
ill test it out and let you know
has anyone had issues with menu icon sizes for the higher resolution devices?
Ex: I’m testing on a galaxy s6
density DPI is 640
menu icon size is 264 x 264
yet, the image is tiny in the action bar
ah crap adding the image makes the parse push too big to allow us to do it
Didn't parse add an option to receive their push and create your own push in your own receiver?
No idea. I personally hate parse. I am assuming you would have to intercept it
You extend their broadcast receiver and do your magic. Just don’t invoke super.onParsePushReceived or something like that
ahhhhhh, yeah I don’t need to invoke onPushReceived until it’s downloaded!
okay, gonna test that out right now
I've been using Parse lately. I kinda like it. it has a lot of limitations but it's so easy to use... I'm trying to build a backend with python on appengine and this is taking me a long time.
I highly recommend that anyone who uses Parse, use the API like a regular API rather than using the SDK. Unless you just like rewriting things.

awesome, it worked
I just don’t call super.onPushReceived
then I start an asynctask to load the bitmap, and then call super.onPushReceived after the bitmap is loaded and just return that bitmap in getLargeIcon
:simple_smile:
Let Picasso or something load your Bitmaps that's more thread safe
AsyncTasks have a pretty bad tendency to leak, particularly with network calls
Most likely wouldn't, but a strong chance
if done right, shouldn't be a problem
things break when ppl declare asynctask inside the activity, or pass such activity to use within the task, and things like that
Right, but rarely do you see devs who don't know better place that AsyncTask as an inner class.
Rather than allowing it to use the static handler.

I don't use them anymore, and I was still getting some leaks. I found out thanks to leakcanary, probably the best library out there. some leaks I didn't even know were happening taught me more than any documentation I've read
LeakCanary is boss.
We have it as a compiledebug. Hasn't found anything yet, but a few other devs in town use it and found some pretty interesting things.
It doesn't work with M preview yet, but I saw a PR in for it.
Just naming errors
well if you didn't leak anything, that's really good :simple_smile:
I've even found leaks in third-party libraries
My app is 90% one activity, would leak canary still help me?
Yeah, that's when it gets nuts <@U0546MZGX>
<@U053Q5XP2> sure, everything can leak

might sound stupid, but the thing I liked the most about LeakCanary is the notification warning you. I liked it so much that I built a wrapper for logging so I print all the messages to the console and some of them raise a notification (so QA or whoever is using the app without having Android Studio open can see important messages)
Didn't really think about to use it for that.
Interesting. Might move it to our qa builds then
What do you display to QA <@U0546MZGX>
things that shouldn't be happening. like when parsing a JSON from our backend. if there is an error, we need to fix it asap, so we show a notification and they tell us.
we're using Glide

I think it's square that uses the "crash fast" approach. I agree, but when you release something to production you might want to show a dialog and recover from that crash instead of just crashing. that is not very user friendly.
Crashlytics lets you log this kind of things, even if the app doesn't crash. But HockeyApp doesn't, it only gets the crashes that really make the app to crash.
so this is my approach for "controlled" crashes that shouldn't be happening
(only for debug releases of course)
yeah it was square <https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=57P86oZXjXs>

attachments.title: Crash Fast: Square’s approach to Android crashes
attachments.fallback: YouTube Video: Crash Fast: Square’s approach to Android crashes

text: I think HockeyApp and Applause are total garbage.
Also, Crashlytics .log function I think is deprecated.
I haven't found the replacement yet, but I haven't spent much time looking

Applause have found some hilariously obscure bugs. Like there was one south american carrier's version of the S3 that claimed to have a flashlight but when you tried to turn it on it said it had no flashlight. But overall they didn't read the documentation and would always report duplicates, so we stopped using them.
<@U0542GLTE>: I didn't know about that deprecation. I only use Crashlytics for personal projects and it's been a while. I hope there is an alternative.
<@U053Q5XP2>: The first crash, every single time I released to QA, would be the window trying to appear every 10 mins with anonymous users.
<@U0546MZGX>: <https://dev.twitter.com/crashlytics/android/caught-exceptions>

attachments.title: Caught Exceptions
attachments.text: In addition to automatically reporting your app’s crashes, Crashlytics for Android lets you log caught exceptions in your app’s catch blocks. Add a call to Crashlytics.getInstance().core.logException(Exception) to your catch block:

text: Just found it
Thanks for more work Crashlytics
that is pretty cool
haha, i do that with bugsense to catch errors that should never ever happen. very very rarely,  calling new Date() throws invalid day of week 0. wtf?
That's only for caught exceptions though
I'm happy with bugsense, or splunk mint express, but my ios counterpart has encounterd a lot of bugs on their ios client. And their netowork monitoring just doesn't work.
